description: Devil weed also known as Siam weed or bitter bush is a highly invasive weed. It has a triangular leaf with triangular edges. The devil weed gets its name from its three main veins that look similar to a pitchfork. Flowering devil weed has purple-white stringy petals and forms in clusters. It rapidly reproduces and creates thick foliage outcompeting native species. They also release toxins into the soil and are toxic to livestock.

The Japanese wireweed or strangle weed is a large brown-yellow seaweed with long blades and spherical olive-looking bulbs. It grows in shallow waters and can attach to hard surfaces, such as rocks, docks, and boats. Its ability to reproduce quickly has hurt native algae.
Wakame or Japanese seaweed is a seaweed with long wavy green-brown fronds attached to a stem. The plant can grow to 3 meters in length. It rapidly grows in dense forests hurting native species.
